Plaintiffs: Homebuyers Mya Batton, Aaron Bolton, Michael Brace, Do Yeon Irene Kim, Anna James, James Mullis and Theodore Bibiscos.
Defendants: Compass, Redfin, Douglas Elliman, eXp Realty and three others
Summary: The complaint argues that NAR's Clear Cooperation Policy rule pressures sellers to offer a high commission to prevent buyer’s agents from steering their clients to homes where they could take home a higher cut.

Plaintiffs: Don Gibson, Lauren Criss and John Meiners
Defendants: NAR, Compass, eXp, Redfin, Weichert Realtors, United Real Estate, Howard Hanna Real Estate Services and Douglas Elliman
Summary: Minutes after a landmark victory over two brokerages and the National Association of Realtors, the plaintiffs’ attorney filed another class-action lawsuit against other residential brokerages, also related to buyers’ agent commissions.

Plaintiffs: A group of Missouri home sellers, led by class representatives Rhonda Burnett, Jerod Breit, Jeremy Keel, Hollee Ellis and Frances Harvey.
Defendants: National Association of Realtors, HomeServices of America and Keller Williams
Summary: A Kansas City jury found NAR, HomeServices of America and Keller Williams guilty of conspiring to keep commissions high under the industry group’s rule dictating commission splits in exchange for access to the MLS.

Plaintiffs: QJ Team and Five Points Holdings, seeking class action status to represent all homesellers in Texas who put their properties on an MLS and paid a buyer broker commission from November 2019 to now.
Defendants: Texas Association of Realtors, Austin Board of Realtors, San Antonio Board of Realtors, MetroTex Association of Realtors, Houston Association of Realtors, and brokerages that include Keller Williams, Fathom Realty and Side.
Summary: Texas-based homebuilder QJ Team and holding company Five Points Holdings are alleging a “concealed conspiracy” similar to the complaints in the landmark Sitzer/Burnett case.

Plaintiffs: Monty March, a New York City homeseller
Defendants: Real Estate Board of New York and 26 brokerages, including Compass, Christie’s International, Corcoran, Douglas Elliman, Modern Spaces, Modlin Group and Brown Harris Stevens
Summary: The class-action complaint alleges REBNY inflated commissions by requiring sellers to pay buyers’ brokers. The lawsuit is hooked on a similar rule in the REBNY Universal Co-Brokerage Agreement that mandated the same policy as NAR with local Multiple Listing Services. New York City does not have a citywide MLS. REBNY updated its agreement in October to include a change that bans listing brokers from paying buyers’ agents and instead requires sellers to pay them directly.

In 2019, the Northwest MLS, which covers Seattle and surrounding areas, eliminated the requirement that a seller offer compensation to the buyer’s broker, and amended its rules to allow listing brokers to publish the commission amount a seller is offering the buyer's broker. In 2022, the Northwest MLS again changed its rules, requiring that the compensation the seller was offering the buyer broker be "prominently stated" on the first page of the purchase and sale agreement.
